title: Authors and Citation
text: Li S, Zhu X, Chen Y, Liu D (2021). “PAsso: R Package Assessing Partial Association Ordinal Variables.” R Journal, 13(2), 239–252. doi:10.32614/RJ-2021-088.
code: @Article{,   title = {PAsso: an R Package for Assessing Partial Association between Ordinal Variables},   author = {Shaobo Li and Xiaorui Zhu and Yuejie Chen and Dungang Liu},   year = {2021},   journal = {The R Journal},   volume = {13},   number = {2},   pages = {239--252},   doi = {10.32614/RJ-2021-088}, }

title: Assessing the Partial Association Between Ordinal Variables
text: implementation unified framework assessing Parrtial Association ordinal variables adjusting set covariates (Dungang Liu, Shaobo Li, Yan Yu Irini Moustaki (2020), accepted Journal American Statistical Association). package provides set tools quantify, visualize, test partial associations multiple ordinal variables. can produce number ϕ measures, partial regression plots, 3-D plots, p-values testing H0 : ϕ = 0 H0 : ϕ ≤ δ

title: Assessing the Partial Association Between Ordinal Variables
text: PAsso package currently available PAsso CRAN.

what: Install PAsso development version from GitHub (recommended)
title: Assessing the Partial Association Between Ordinal Variables
code: # Install the development version from GitHub if (!requireNamespace("devtools")) install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("XiaoruiZhu/PAsso")

title: Assessing the Partial Association Between Ordinal Variables
code: # Install from CRAN install.packages("PAsso")  # For macOS, if you have "error: 'math.h' file not found" for installing PAsso v0.1.9, # the solution could be: install.packages("https://cran.r-project.org/bin/macosx/el-capitan/contrib/3.6/PAsso_0.1.9.tgz",                    repos = NULL, type = "source")                    # If error "there is no package called 'gsl'" comes, try: install.packages("gsl", type = "mac.binary")

title: Assessing the Partial Association Between Ordinal Variables
text: following example shows R code evaluating partial association binary variable PreVote.num ordinal variable PID, adjusting age, education, income. Specifically, PreVote.num respondent’s voting preference Donald Trump Hilary Clinton. PID respondent’s party identification 7 ordinal levels strong democrat (=1) strong republication (=7). data set drawn 2016 American National Election Study.
code: library(PAsso)  PAsso_1 <- PAsso(responses = c("PreVote.num", "PID"),                  adjustments = c("income.num", "age", "edu.year"),                  data = ANES2016,                  uni.model = "probit",                  method = c("kendall"))  # Print the partial association matrix only print(PAsso_1, 5)  # Provide: # 1. partial association matrix; # 2. marginal association matrix for comparison purpose; # 3. summary of models' coefficients for model diagnostics and interpretation summary(PAsso_1, 4)  # Plot partial association regression plot: residuals plot(PAsso_1)  # Retrieve residuals that are used as ingredients for partial assocaition analyses test_resids <- residuals(PAsso_1, draw = 1) head(test_resids)  # test function: Conduct inference based on object of "PAsso.test" class ---------------------------- library(progress);  system.time(Pcor_SR_test1 <- test(object = PAsso_1, bootstrap_rep = 100, H0 = 0, parallel = F)) print(Pcor_SR_test1, digits=6)  # diagnostic.plot function ----------------------------------------------------- check_qq <- diagnostic.plot(object = PAsso_1, output = "qq")  check_fitted <- diagnostic.plot(object = PAsso_1, output = "fitted")  check_covar <- diagnostic.plot(object = PAsso_1, output = "covariate")  # Or more specific, draw residual-vs-covariate plot for the second model with # response "PID" and covariate "income.num"  diagnostic.plot(object = PAsso_1, output = "covariate", x_name = "income.num", model_id = 2)  # general association measure and 3-D plot for VOTE and PID ------------------ library("copula"); library("plotly")  # Draw all pairs testPlots <- plot3D(PAsso_1) testPlots$`PreVote.num v.s. PID`  # Draw just one pair testPlots2 <- plot3D(object = PAsso_1, y1 = "PreVote.num", y2 = "PID") testPlots2  # "PAsso" advanced using of the function: Input a few models directly ------------------------------ fit_vote <- glm(PreVote.num ~ income.num + age + edu.year, data = ANES2016,                 family = binomial(link = "probit")) summary(fit_vote)  library(MASS) fit_PID <- polr(as.factor(PID) ~ income.num + age + edu.year, data = ANES2016,                 method = "probit", Hess = TRUE)  summary(fit_PID)  system.time(PAsso_adv1 <- PAsso(fitted.models=list(fit_vote, fit_PID),                                 association = c("partial"),                                 method = c("kendall"),                                 resids.type = "surrogate") )  # Partial association coefficients  print(PAsso_adv1, digits = 3) summary(PAsso_adv1, digits = 3)

title: Assessing the Partial Association Between Ordinal Variables
text: Li et al. (2021). PAsso: R Package Assessing Partial Association Ordinal Variables. R Journal, 13(2), 239–252, <10.32614/RJ-2021-088> Liu, D., Li, S., Yu, Y., & Moustaki, . (2020). Assessing partial association ordinal variables: quantification, visualization, hypothesis testing. Journal American Statistical Association, 1-14. <10.1080/01621459.2020.1796394> Liu, D., & Zhang, H. (2018). Residuals diagnostics ordinal regression models: surrogate approach. Journal American Statistical Association, 113(522), 845-854. <10.1080/01621459.2017.1292915> Greenwell, B.M., McCarthy, .J., Boehmke, B.C. & Liu, D. (2018) Residuals diagnostics binary ordinal regression models: introduction sure package. R Journal. <10.32614/RJ-2018-004>

what: The 2016 ANES Time Series Study with pre-election interview — ANES2016
title: The 2016 ANES Time Series Study with pre-election interview — ANES2016
text: subset 2,188 participants 2016 American National Election Time Series Study, track enduring social trend record political moment 2016 (DeBell, 2018). study consisted two surveys population. pre-election interview weeks 2016 general election, including 4,271 respondents total. post-election interview re-interview weeks election, including 3,649 respondents (662 respondents complete post-interviews).

title: The 2016 ANES Time Series Study with pre-election interview — ANES2016
code: data(ANES2016)

title: The 2016 ANES Time Series Study with pre-election interview — ANES2016
text: data frame 2188 rows 10 variables. age Respondent's age years. edu.year Respondent's education year, mapped education   level: MS=8, HSdrop=11, HS=12, Coll=14,   CCdeg=15, BAdeg=17, MAdeg=19. education Respondent's education level. income.num Respondent's family income thousands: numerical variable.   median value range income level income Respondent's family income level: '(01) 01. $5,000' = 5, '(02) 02. $5,000-$9,999', '(03) 03. $10,000-$12,499', '(04) 04. $12,500-$14,999', '(05) 05. $15,000-$17,499', '(06) 06. $17,500-$19,999', '(07) 07. $20,000-$22,499', '(08) 08. $22,500-$24,999', '(09) 09. $25,000-$27,499', '(10) 10. $27,500-$29,999', '(11) 11. $30,000-$34,999', '(12) 12. $35,000-$39,999', '(13) 13. $40,000-$44,999', '(14) 14. $45,000-$49,999', '(15) 15. $50,000-$54,999', '(16) 16. $55,000-$59,999', '(17) 17. $60,000-$64,999', '(18) 18. $65,000-$69,999', '(19) 19. $70,000-$74,999', '(20) 20. $75,000-$79,999', '(21) 21. $80,000-$89,999', '(22) 22. $90,000-$99,999', '(23) 23. $100,000-$109,999', '(24) 24. $110,000-$124,999', '(25) 25. $125,000-$149,999', '(26) 26. $150,000-$174,999', '(27) 27. $175,000-$249,999', '(28) 28. $250,000 ' = 250. PID Party identification: numeric variable value 1 7   representing strong Democrat, strDem < weak Democrat, weakDem <   independent Democrat, indDem < independent independent indind <   independent Republican, indRep < weak Republican, weakRep <   strong Republican, strRep. selfLR respondent' self-placement left-right 7 ordinal levels   (extremely liberal extremely conservative). extLib: extremely liberal, Lib: liberal,   sliLib: slightly liberal, Mod: moderate, sliCon:   slightly conservative, Con: conservative, extCon: extremely   conservative. extLib < Lib < sliLib <   Mod < sliCon < Con < extCon. TrumpLR respondent's opinion Donald Trump's left-right   placement (scale selfLR). ClinLR respondent's opinion Hilary Clinton's left-right   placement (scale selfLR). PreVote respondent's voting preference   Donald Trump Hilary Clinton two months preceeding   November election (Pre-election interview). factor levels   HillaryClinton DonaldTrump. PreVote.num Recode PreVote numeric values,   'HillaryClinton'=0, 'DonaldTrump'=1. WeightforPreVote Pre-election weight respondent.

title: The 2016 ANES Time Series Study with pre-election interview — ANES2016
text: Pre-election preference recorded "PreVote" "PreVote.num" numeric . Observations missing values, "thought" responses removed. Respondents expressing voting preference Clinton Trump removed.

Sociological Methods & Research, 2018. doi:10.1177/0049124118769085 Enamorado, T., Fifield, B., & Imai, K. (2018). User’s guide codebook ANES 2016 time series voter validation supplemental data. Technical Report, American National Election Studies.

what: Partial association analysis between ordinal responses after adjusting for a set of covariates — PAsso
title: Partial association analysis between ordinal responses after adjusting for a set of covariates — PAsso
text: function mainly designed conducting partial association analysis. provides two ways using: 1. user-friendly way: need "responses", "adjustments", "data". rest argument setted default (see Arguments details default). 2. advanced way: user can input list fitted models "fitted.models", "responses" "adjustments" necessary. Supported class cumulative link models clm, glm, lrm, orm, polr, vglm, . generates object partial association matrix, marginal association, attributes: "arguments" saves c(association, method, resids.type). "responses" contains names response variables. attribute "adjustments" contains names covariates. "summary" function "PAsso" class object provides marginal association ' matrix comparison purpose.

title: Partial association analysis between ordinal responses after adjusting for a set of covariates — PAsso
code: PAsso(   responses,   adjustments,   data,   uni.model = c("probit", "logit", "acat"),   models = NULL,   method = c("kendall", "pearson", "wolfsigma"),   resids.type = c("surrogate", "sign", "general", "deviance"),   jitter = c("latent", "uniform"),   jitter.uniform.scale = c("probability", "response"),   fitted.models = NULL,   n_draws = 20,   association = "partial",   ... )

title: Partial association analysis between ordinal responses after adjusting for a set of covariates — PAsso
text: responses string vector specifies response variables. requires equal greater two variables data frame. adjustments string vector specifies covariates/confounders need adjusted. data data.frame including responses adjustments. uni.model character string specifying one single universal model setting responses. Default "logit" refers cumulative logit model. "probit" refers cumulative probit model. "acat" fits adjacent categories regression model. models string vector contains default link functions fitting models respect response variable. "models" missing one model unspecified, "uni.model" used specify models responses automatically. , argument higher priority "uni.model" long length "models" equals number "responses". method string argument specify correlation coefficient method. Three choices c("kendall", "pearson", "wolfsigma"). default "kendall" resids.type character string specifying type residuals generate Current options include "surrogate", "sign", "general", "deviance". Default "surrogate" residuals. surrogate surrogate residuals (Liu Zhang, 2017); sign sign-based residuals (Li Shepherd, 2010, 2012); general generalized residuals (Franses Paap, 2001); deviance deviance residuals (-2*loglik). Although "sign", "general", "deviance" provided package, residuals problematic partial association analysis ordinal response (discussions see Liu, Dungang, Li, Shaobo, Yu, Yan, Moustaki, Irini.(2020)) jitter character string specifying generate surrogate residuals. Current options "latent" "uniform". Default "latent". latent surrogate residuals. uniform sign-based residuals. jitter.uniform.scale character string specifying scale perform jittering whenever jitter = "uniform". details: PAsso::residuals. fitted.models list contains models (S3 objects) want assess partial association ordinal responses adjusting set covariates covariates. models applied dataset, covariates, sample size etc. models list can object class clm, glm, lrm, orm, polr, vglm. n_draws number specify draws surrogate residuls partial correlation coefficients calculated repeatedly. final correlation coefficients average partial correlation coefficients. "nsim" argument "residuals()" function. association default argument specify partial association. Leave development package association analyses can embedded. ... Additional optional arguments.

title: Partial association analysis between ordinal responses after adjusting for a set of covariates — PAsso
text: object class "PAsso" list containing least following components. contains partial correlation matrix multiple repeats n_draws > 1. object "arguments" attribute saved c(association, method, resids.type), "responses" attribute, "adjustments" attribute. list contains: corr estimated correlation matrix(average rep_MatCorr)   partial association adjusting confounders; rep_corr replications estimated correlation matrix; rep_SRs replications surrogate residuals partial association applied; fitted.models list stores fitted.models; data data.frame original dataset; mods_n sample size fitted model; cor_func correlation function assign different method; Marg_corr marginal association matrix.

title: Partial association analysis between ordinal responses after adjusting for a set of covariates — PAsso
text: Liu, D., Li, S., Yu, Y., & Moustaki, . (2020). Assessing partial association ordinal variables: quantification, visualization, hypothesis testing. Journal American Statistical Association, 1-14. doi:10.1080/01621459.2020.1796394 Liu, D., & Zhang, H. (2018). Residuals diagnostics ordinal regression models: surrogate approach. Journal American Statistical Association, 113(522), 845-854. doi:10.1080/01621459.2017.1292915 Li, C., & Shepherd, B. E. (2010). Test association two ordinal variables adjusting covariates. Journal American Statistical Association, 105(490), 612-620. doi:10.1198/jasa.2010.tm09386 Li, C., & Shepherd, B. E. (2012). new residual ordinal outcomes. Biometrika, 99(2), 473-480. doi:10.1093/biomet/asr073 Franses, P. H., & Paap, R. (2001). Quantitative models marketing research. Cambridge University Press. doi:10.1017/CBO9780511753794

title: Partial association analysis between ordinal responses after adjusting for a set of covariates — PAsso
code: ########################################################### # User-friendly way of using ########################################################### library(MASS)  # Import ANES2016 data in "PAsso" data(ANES2016)  # User-friendly way of the partial association analysis PAsso_1 <- PAsso(responses = c("PreVote.num", "PID"),                 adjustments = c("income.num", "age", "edu.year"),                 data = ANES2016,                 method = c("kendall"))  print(PAsso_1, digits = 4) #> --------------------------------------------  #> The partial correlation coefficient matrix:  #>              PreVote.num  PID   #> PreVote.num  1.000        0.449 #> PID                       1.000 summary(PAsso_1, digits = 4) #> --------------------------------------------  #> The partial correlation coefficient matrix:  #>  #>              PreVote.num  PID   #> PreVote.num  1.000        0.449 #> PID                       1.000 #> --------------------------------------------  #> The marginal correlation coefficient matrix:  #>  #>              PreVote.num  PID    #> PreVote.num  1.0000       0.7059 #> PID                       1.0000 #>  #> -------------------------------------------- #> -------------------------------------------- #>  #> The coefficients of fitted models are:  #>  #>             PreVote.num  PID        #> income.num   0.0005       0.0009*   #> Std. Error   0.0005       0.0004    #> ---                                 #> age          0.0092***    0.0048*** #> Std. Error   0.0016       0.0013    #> ---                                 #> edu.year    -0.0798***   -0.0459*** #> Std. Error   0.0117       0.0098    #> ---                                 #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1  ########################################################### # Advanced way of the partial association analysis ###########################################################  fit.vote<- glm(PreVote.num ~ income.num+ age + edu.year, data = ANES2016,                family = binomial(link = "probit")) fit.PID<- polr(as.factor(PID) ~ income.num+age+edu.year, data = ANES2016,                method="probit", Hess = TRUE)  PAsso_adv1 <- PAsso(fitted.models=list(fit.vote, fit.PID),                     method = c("kendall"),                     resids.type = "surrogate")  print(PAsso_adv1, digits = 4) #> --------------------------------------------  #> The partial correlation coefficient matrix:  #>                 PreVote.num  as.factor(PID) #> PreVote.num     1.0000       0.4487         #> as.factor(PID)               1.0000         summary(PAsso_adv1, digits = 4) #> --------------------------------------------  #> The partial correlation coefficient matrix:  #>  #>                 PreVote.num  as.factor(PID) #> PreVote.num     1.0000       0.4487         #> as.factor(PID)               1.0000         #> --------------------------------------------  #> The marginal correlation coefficient matrix:  #>  #>                 PreVote.num  as.factor(PID) #> PreVote.num     1.0000       0.7059         #> as.factor(PID)               1.0000         #>  #> -------------------------------------------- #> -------------------------------------------- #>  #> The coefficients of fitted models are:  #>  #>             PreVote.num  as.factor(PID) #> income.num   0.0005       0.0009*       #> Std. Error   0.0005       0.0004        #> ---                                     #> age          0.0092***    0.0048***     #> Std. Error   0.0016       0.0013        #> ---                                     #> edu.year    -0.0798***   -0.0459***     #> Std. Error   0.0117       0.0098        #> ---                                     #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1

title: Residual-based diagnostic plots — autoplot
text: Residual-based diagnostic plots cumulative link general regression models using ggplot graphics.

title: Residual-based diagnostic plots — autoplot
code: # S3 method for resid autoplot(   object,   output = c("qq", "fitted", "covariate"),   x = NULL,   fit = NULL,   distribution = qnorm,   ncol = NULL,   alpha = 1,   xlab = NULL,   color = "#444444",   shape = 19,   size = 2,   qqpoint.color = "#444444",   qqpoint.shape = 19,   qqpoint.size = 2,   qqline.color = "#888888",   qqline.linetype = "dashed",   qqline.size = 1,   smooth = TRUE,   smooth.color = "red",   smooth.linetype = 1,   smooth.size = 1,   fill = NULL,   resp_name = NULL,   ... )  # S3 method for glm autoplot(   object,   output = c("qq", "fitted", "covariate"),   x = NULL,   fit = NULL,   distribution = qnorm,   ncol = NULL,   alpha = 1,   xlab = NULL,   color = "#444444",   shape = 19,   size = 2,   qqpoint.color = "#444444",   qqpoint.shape = 19,   qqpoint.size = 2,   qqline.color = "#888888",   qqline.linetype = "dashed",   qqline.size = 1,   smooth = TRUE,   smooth.color = "red",   smooth.linetype = 1,   smooth.size = 1,   fill = NULL,   resp_name = NULL,   ... )  # S3 method for clm autoplot(   object,   output = c("qq", "fitted", "covariate"),   x = NULL,   fit = NULL,   distribution = qnorm,   ncol = NULL,   alpha = 1,   xlab = NULL,   color = "#444444",   shape = 19,   size = 2,   qqpoint.color = "#444444",   qqpoint.shape = 19,   qqpoint.size = 2,   qqline.color = "#888888",   qqline.linetype = "dashed",   qqline.size = 1,   smooth = TRUE,   smooth.color = "red",   smooth.linetype = 1,   smooth.size = 1,   fill = NULL,   resp_name = NULL,   ... )  # S3 method for lrm autoplot(   object,   output = c("qq", "fitted", "covariate"),   x = NULL,   fit = NULL,   distribution = qnorm,   ncol = NULL,   alpha = 1,   xlab = NULL,   color = "#444444",   shape = 19,   size = 2,   qqpoint.color = "#444444",   qqpoint.shape = 19,   qqpoint.size = 2,   qqline.color = "#888888",   qqline.linetype = "dashed",   qqline.size = 1,   smooth = TRUE,   smooth.color = "red",   smooth.linetype = 1,   smooth.size = 1,   fill = NULL,   resp_name = NULL,   ... )  # S3 method for orm autoplot(   object,   output = c("qq", "fitted", "covariate"),   x = NULL,   fit = NULL,   distribution = qnorm,   ncol = NULL,   alpha = 1,   xlab = NULL,   color = "#444444",   shape = 19,   size = 2,   qqpoint.color = "#444444",   qqpoint.shape = 19,   qqpoint.size = 2,   qqline.color = "#888888",   qqline.linetype = "dashed",   qqline.size = 1,   smooth = TRUE,   smooth.color = "red",   smooth.linetype = 1,   smooth.size = 1,   fill = NULL,   resp_name = NULL,   ... )  # S3 method for polr autoplot(   object,   output = c("qq", "fitted", "covariate"),   x = NULL,   fit = NULL,   distribution = qnorm,   ncol = NULL,   alpha = 1,   xlab = NULL,   color = "#444444",   shape = 19,   size = 2,   qqpoint.color = "#444444",   qqpoint.shape = 19,   qqpoint.size = 2,   qqline.color = "#888888",   qqline.linetype = "dashed",   qqline.size = 1,   smooth = TRUE,   smooth.color = "red",   smooth.linetype = 1,   smooth.size = 1,   fill = NULL,   resp_name = NULL,   ... )  # S3 method for vglm autoplot(   object,   output = c("qq", "fitted", "covariate"),   x = NULL,   fit = NULL,   distribution = qnorm,   ncol = NULL,   alpha = 1,   xlab = NULL,   color = "#444444",   shape = 19,   size = 2,   qqpoint.color = "#444444",   qqpoint.shape = 19,   qqpoint.size = 2,   qqline.color = "#888888",   qqline.linetype = "dashed",   qqline.size = 1,   smooth = TRUE,   smooth.color = "red",   smooth.linetype = 1,   smooth.size = 1,   fill = NULL,   resp_name = NULL,   ... )

title: Residual-based diagnostic plots — autoplot
text: object object class sure:resids, clm, glm, lrm, orm, polr, vglm. output Character string specifying plot. Default "qq" produces quantile-quantile plots residuals. x vector giving covariate values use residual-- covariate plots (.e., output = "covariate"). fit fitted model residuals extracted. (required output = "fitted" object inherits class "resid".) distribution Function computes quantiles reference distribution use quantile-quantile plot. Default qnorm appropriate models using probit link function. jitter.scale = "probability", reference distribution always U(-0.5, 0.5). (required object inherits class "resid".) ncol Integer specifying number columns use plot layout (requesting multiple plots). Default NULL. alpha single values interval [0, 1] controlling opacity alpha plotted points. used nsim > 1. xlab Character string giving text use x-axis label residual--covariate plots. Default NULL. color Character string integer specifying color use points residual vs fitted value/covariate plot. Default "black". shape Integer single character specifying symbol used plotting points residual vs fitted value/covariate plot. size Numeric value specifying size use points residual vs fitted value/covariate plot. qqpoint.color Character string integer specifying color use points quantile-quantile plot. qqpoint.shape Integer single character specifying symbol used plotting points quantile-quantile plot. qqpoint.size Numeric value specifying size use points quantile-quantile plot. qqline.color Character string integer specifying color use points quantile-quantile plot. qqline.linetype Integer character string (e.g., "dashed") specifying type line use quantile-quantile plot. qqline.size Numeric value specifying thickness line quantile-quantile plot. smooth Logical indicating whether add nonparametric smooth certain plots. Default TRUE. smooth.color Character string integer specifying color use nonparametric smooth. smooth.linetype Integer character string (e.g., "dashed") specifying type line use nonparametric smooth. smooth.size Numeric value specifying thickness line nonparametric smooth. fill Character string integer specifying color use fill boxplots residual--covariate plots x class "factor". Default NULL colors boxplots according factor levels. resp_name Character string specify response name displayed figure. ... Additional optional arguments passed onto ggplot.

title: Residual-based diagnostic plots — autoplot
text: "ggplot" object. "ggplot" object.

title: Residual-based diagnostic plots — autoplot
code: # Load data data(df1) # Fit cumulative link model fit <- glm(y ~ x + I(x ^ 2), data = df1, family = binomial) # Construct residual plots p1 <- ggplot2::autoplot(fit, jitter.scale = "probability", output = "qq") p2 <- ggplot2::autoplot(fit, output = "covariate", x = df1$x) p3 <- ggplot2::autoplot(fit, output = "fitted")

title: Simulated quadratic data — df1
text: Data simulated probit model quadratic trend. data described Example 2 Liu Zhang (2017).

title: Simulated quadratic data — df1
code: data(df1)

title: Simulated quadratic data — df1
text: data frame 2000 rows 2 variables. x predictor variable. y response variable; ordered factor.

title: Simulated quadratic data — df1
text: Liu, Dungang Zhang, Heping. Residuals Diagnostics Ordinal Regression Models: Surrogate Approach. Journal American Statistical Association

title: Residual-based diagnostic plots — diagnostic.plot
text: set visualization tools diagnostic fitted model partial association analysis. can provides plot matrix including Q-Q plots, residual-vs-fitted plots, residual-vs-covariate plots fitted models. function also support direct diagnostic cumulative link regression model class clm, glm, lrm, orm, polr. Currently, vglm supported.

title: Residual-based diagnostic plots — diagnostic.plot
code: diagnostic.plot(object, ...)  # S3 method for default diagnostic.plot(object, ...)  # S3 method for resid diagnostic.plot(object, output = c("qq", "fitted", "covariate"), ...)  # S3 method for PAsso diagnostic.plot(   object,   output = c("qq", "fitted", "covariate"),   model_id = NULL,   x_name = NULL,   ... )  # S3 method for glm diagnostic.plot(   object,   output = c("qq", "fitted", "covariate"),   x = NULL,   fit = NULL,   distribution = qnorm,   ncol = NULL,   alpha = 1,   xlab = NULL,   color = "#444444",   shape = 19,   size = 2,   qqpoint.color = "#444444",   qqpoint.shape = 19,   qqpoint.size = 2,   qqline.color = "#888888",   qqline.linetype = "dashed",   qqline.size = 1,   smooth = TRUE,   smooth.color = "red",   smooth.linetype = 1,   smooth.size = 1,   fill = NULL,   resp_name = NULL,   ... )  # S3 method for clm diagnostic.plot(object, output = c("qq", "fitted", "covariate"), ...)  # S3 method for lrm diagnostic.plot(object, output = c("qq", "fitted", "covariate"), ...)  # S3 method for orm diagnostic.plot(object, output = c("qq", "fitted", "covariate"), ...)  # S3 method for polr diagnostic.plot(object, output = c("qq", "fitted", "covariate"), ...)

title: Residual-based diagnostic plots — diagnostic.plot
text: object object support classes (function mainly designed PAsso). ... Additional optional arguments can passed onto ggplot drawing various plots. output character string specifying type output plot. Default "qq" produces plot matrix quantile-quantile plots residuals. "fitted" produces plot matrix residuals corresponding fitted responses. "covariates" produces plot matrix residuals corresponding covariate. model_id number refers index model needs diagnosed. NULL, models diagnosed. x_name string refers covariate name needs diagnosed. NULL, adjustments diagnosed. x vector giving covariate values use residual-- covariate plots (.e., output = "covariate"). fit fitted model residuals extracted. (required output = "fitted" object inherits class "resid".) distribution Function computes quantiles reference distribution use quantile-quantile plot. Default qnorm appropriate models using probit link function. jitter.scale = "probability", reference distribution always U(-0.5, 0.5). (required object inherits class "resid".) ncol Integer specifying number columns use plot layout (requesting multiple plots). Default NULL. alpha single values interval [0, 1] controlling opacity alpha plotted points. used nsim > 1. xlab Character string giving text use x-axis label residual--covariate plots. Default NULL. color Character string integer specifying color use points residual vs fitted value/covariate plot. Default "black". shape Integer single character specifying symbol used plotting points residual vs fitted value/covariate plot. size Numeric value specifying size use points residual vs fitted value/covariate plot. qqpoint.color Character string integer specifying color use points quantile-quantile plot. qqpoint.shape Integer single character specifying symbol used plotting points quantile-quantile plot. qqpoint.size Numeric value specifying size use points quantile-quantile plot. qqline.color Character string integer specifying color use points quantile-quantile plot. qqline.linetype Integer character string (e.g., "dashed") specifying type line use quantile-quantile plot. qqline.size Numeric value specifying thickness line quantile-quantile plot. smooth Logical indicating whether add nonparametric smooth certain plots. Default TRUE. smooth.color Character string integer specifying color use nonparametric smooth. smooth.linetype Integer character string (e.g., "dashed") specifying type line use nonparametric smooth. smooth.size Numeric value specifying thickness line nonparametric smooth. fill Character string integer specifying color use fill boxplots residual--covariate plots x class "factor". Default NULL colors boxplots according factor levels. resp_name Character string specify response name displayed figure.

title: Residual-based diagnostic plots — diagnostic.plot
text: "ggplot" object supported models. class "PAsso", returns plot "gtable" object combines diagnostic plots responses. "ggplot" object based input residuals. "ggplot" object based input residuals. plot "gtable" object combines diagnostic plots responses. "ggplot" object based residuals generated glm object. "ggplot" object based residuals generated clm object. "ggplot" object based residuals generated lrm object. "ggplot" object based residuals generated orm object. "ggplot" object based residuals generated polr object.

title: Residual-based diagnostic plots — diagnostic.plot
code: # Import data for partial association analysis data("ANES2016") ANES2016$PreVote.num <- as.factor(ANES2016$PreVote.num)  PAsso_3v <- PAsso(responses = c("PreVote.num", "PID", "selfLR"),                   adjustments = c("income.num", "age", "edu.year"),                   data = ANES2016, uni.model = "probit",                   method = c("kendall"),                   resids.type = "surrogate", jitter = "latent")  diag_p1 <- diagnostic.plot(object = PAsso_3v, output = "qq")  diag_p2 <- diagnostic.plot(object = PAsso_3v, output = "fitted")  diag_p3 <- diagnostic.plot(object = PAsso_3v, output = "covariate") #> No covariate is specified, the first covariate(adjustment) is being used. #> Warning: Computation failed in `stat_smooth()` #> Caused by error in `smooth.construct.cr.smooth.spec()`: #> ! x has insufficient unique values to support 10 knots: reduce k. #> Warning: Computation failed in `stat_smooth()` #> Caused by error in `smooth.construct.cr.smooth.spec()`: #> ! x has insufficient unique values to support 10 knots: reduce k. #> Warning: Computation failed in `stat_smooth()` #> Caused by error in `smooth.construct.cr.smooth.spec()`: #> ! x has insufficient unique values to support 10 knots: reduce k.   # Simply diagnose a model # Fit cumulative link models  fit1 <- ordinal::clm(PreVote.num ~ income.num + age + edu.year, data = ANES2016, link = "logit")  # diagnostic.plot plot_qq_1 <- diagnostic.plot(object = fit1, output = "qq") plot_fit_1 <- diagnostic.plot(object = fit1, output = "fitted") plot_cov_1 <- diagnostic.plot(object = fit1, output = "covariate") #> No covariate `x` is specified, extract the first covariate from `fit`.

title: Extract Model Residuals — residuals
text: generic function simulate surrogate residuals cumulative link regression models using latent method described Liu Zhang (2017). also support sign-based residuals (Li Shepherd, 2010), generalized residuals (Franses Paap, 2001), deviance residuals cumulative link regression models.

title: Extract Model Residuals — residuals
code: # S3 method for clm residuals(   object,   type = c("surrogate", "sign", "general", "deviance"),   jitter = c("latent", "uniform"),   jitter.uniform.scale = c("probability", "response"),   nsim = 1L,   ... )  # S3 method for ord residuals(   object,   type = c("surrogate", "sign", "general", "deviance", "pearson", "working", "response",     "partial"),   jitter = c("latent", "uniform"),   jitter.uniform.scale = c("probability", "response"),   nsim = 1L,   ... )  # S3 method for lrm residuals(   object,   type = c("surrogate", "sign", "general", "deviance"),   jitter = c("latent", "uniform"),   jitter.uniform.scale = c("probability", "response"),   nsim = 1L,   ... )  # S3 method for orm residuals(   object,   type = c("surrogate", "sign", "general", "deviance"),   jitter = c("latent", "uniform"),   jitter.uniform.scale = c("probability", "response"),   nsim = 1L,   ... )  # S3 method for polr residuals(   object,   type = c("surrogate", "sign", "general", "deviance"),   jitter = c("latent", "uniform"),   jitter.uniform.scale = c("probability", "response"),   nsim = 1L,   ... )  # S3 method for glm residuals(   object,   type = c("surrogate", "sign", "general", "deviance", "pearson", "working", "response",     "partial"),   jitter = c("latent", "uniform"),   jitter.uniform.scale = c("probability", "response"),   nsim = 1L,   ... )  # S4 method for vglm residuals(   object,   type = c("surrogate", "sign", "general", "deviance"),   jitter = c("latent", "uniform"),   jitter.uniform.scale = c("probability", "response"),   nsim = 1L,   ... )  # S4 method for vgam residuals(   object,   type = c("surrogate", "sign", "general", "deviance"),   jitter = c("latent", "uniform"),   jitter.uniform.scale = c("probability", "response"),   nsim = 1L,   ... )  # S3 method for PAsso residuals(object, draw_id = 1, ...)

title: Extract Model Residuals — residuals
text: object object class PAsso. type type residuals returned. alternatives : "surrogate" (default), "sign", "general", "deviance". Can abbreviated. surrogate surrogate residuals (Liu Zhang, 2017); sign sign-based residuals; general generalized residuals (Franses Paap, 2001); deviance deviance residuals (-2*loglik). jitter type = "surrogate", argument character string specifying method use generate surrogate response values. Current options "latent" "uniform". Default "latent". latent latent approach; uniform jittering uniform approach. jitter.uniform.scale jitter = "uniform", character string specifying scale perform jittering whenever jitter = "uniform". Current options "response" "probability". Default "response". nsim integer specifying number replicates use. Default 1L meaning one simulation residuals. ... Additional optional arguments. draw_id number refers -th draw residuals.

title: Extract Model Residuals — residuals
text: numeric vector class c("numeric", "resids") containing simulated surrogate residuals. Additionally, nsim > 1, result contain attributes: draws matrix nsim columns, one   replicate surrogate residuals. Note, correspond   original ordering data; draws_id matrix  nsim columns. column   contains observation number surrogate residuals corresponds   draws. (used plotting purposes.) "resid" object attributes. contains vector matrix (nsim>1) residuals adjacent categories model. matrix class c("matrix", "resids") containing simulated surrogate residuals used partial association analysis PAsso. Additionally, rep_num > 1 PAsso, result contain attributes: draws array contains draws residuals.

title: Extract Model Residuals — residuals
text: Surrogate response values require sampling continuous distribution; consequently, result different every call surrogate. internal functions used sampling truncated distributions based modified versions rtrunc qtrunc. "glm" objects, binomial() family supported.

title: Extract Model Residuals — residuals
text: Liu, D., Li, S., Yu, Y., & Moustaki, . (2020). Assessing partial association ordinal variables: quantification, visualization, hypothesis testing. Journal American Statistical Association, 1-14. doi:10.1080/01621459.2020.1796394 Liu, D., & Zhang, H. (2018). Residuals diagnostics ordinal regression models: surrogate approach. Journal American Statistical Association, 113(522), 845-854. doi:10.1080/01621459.2017.1292915 Li, C., & Shepherd, B. E. (2010). Test association two ordinal variables adjusting covariates. Journal American Statistical Association, 105(490), 612-620. doi:10.1198/jasa.2010.tm09386 Franses, P. H., & Paap, R. (2001). Quantitative models marketing research. Cambridge University Press. doi:10.1017/CBO9780511753794

title: Extract Model Residuals — residuals
code: # Generate data from a quadratic probit model set.seed(101) n <- 2000 x <- runif(n, min = -3, max = 6) z <- 10 + 3 * x - 1 * x^2 + rnorm(n) y <- ifelse(z <= 0, yes = 0, no = 1)  # Scatterplot matrix pairs(~ x + y + z)   # Misspecified mean structure fm1 <- glm(y ~ x, family = binomial(link = "probit")) diagnostic.plot(fm1) #> No covariate `x` is specified, extract the first covariate from `fit`.   # Correctly specified mean structure fm2 <- glm(y ~ x + I(x ^ 2), family = binomial(link = "probit")) #> Warning: glm.fit: fitted probabilities numerically 0 or 1 occurred diagnostic.plot(fm2) #> No covariate `x` is specified, extract the first covariate from `fit`.   # Load data data("ANES2016") PAsso_1 <- PAsso(responses = c("PreVote.num", "PID"),                  adjustments = c("income.num", "age", "edu.year"),                  data = ANES2016)  # Compute residuals res1 <- residuals(PAsso_1)

Default "latent". latent latent approach; uniform jittering uniform approach. jitter.uniform.scale character string specifying scale perform jittering whenever jitter = "uniform". title: Surrogate response — surrogate
text: Simulate surrogate response values cumulative link regression models using latent method described Liu Zhang (2017).

title: Surrogate response — surrogate
code: surrogate(   object,   method = c("latent", "uniform"),   jitter.uniform.scale = c("probability", "response"),   nsim = 1L,   ... )

title: Surrogate response — surrogate
text: object object class clm, glm lrm, orm, polr, vglm. method Character string specifying method use generate surrogate response values. Current options "latent" "uniform". Default "latent". jitter.uniform.scale Character string specifying scale perform jittering whenever method = "uniform". Current options "response" "probability". Default "response". nsim Integer specifying number bootstrap replicates use. Default 1L meaning bootstrap samples. ... Additional optional arguments. (Currently ignored.)

title: Surrogate response — surrogate
text: numeric vector class c("numeric", "surrogate") containing simulated surrogate response values. Additionally, nsim > 1, result contain attributes: boot_reps matrix  nsim columns, one   bootstrap replicate surrogate values. Note, random   correspond original ordering data; boot_id matrix  nsim columns. column   contains observation number surrogate value corresponds   boot_reps. (used plotting purposes.)

title: Surrogate response — surrogate
text: Surrogate response values require sampling continuous distribution; consequently, result different every call surrogate. internal functions used sampling truncated distributions based modified versions truncdist:rtrunc truncdist:qtrunc. "glm" objects, binomial() family supported.

title: Surrogate response — surrogate
text: Liu, D., Li, S., Yu, Y., & Moustaki, . (2020). Assessing partial association ordinal variables: quantification, visualization, hypothesis testing. Journal American Statistical Association, 1-14. doi:10.1080/01621459.2020.1796394 Liu, D., & Zhang, H. (2018). Residuals diagnostics ordinal regression models: surrogate approach. Journal American Statistical Association, 113(522), 845-854. doi:10.1080/01621459.2017.1292915 Nadarajah, S., & Kotz, S. (2006). R Programs Truncated Distributions. Journal Statistical Software, 16(Code Snippet 2), 1 - 8. doi:10.18637/jss.v016.c02

title: Surrogate response — surrogate
code: # Generate data from a quadratic probit model set.seed(101) n <- 2000 x <- runif(n, min = -3, max = 6) z <- 10 + 3*x - 1*x^2 + rnorm(n) y <- ifelse(z <= 0, yes = 0, no = 1)  # Scatterplot matrix pairs(~ x + y + z)   # Setup for side-by-side plots par(mfrow = c(1, 2))  # Misspecified mean structure fm1 <- glm(y ~ x, family = binomial(link = "probit")) s1 <- surrogate(fm1) scatter.smooth(x, s1 - fm1$linear.predictors,                main = "Misspecified model",                ylab = "Surrogate residual",                lpars = list(lwd = 3, col = "red2")) abline(h = 0, lty = 2, col = "blue2")  # Correctly specified mean structure fm2 <- glm(y ~ x + I(x ^ 2), family = binomial(link = "probit")) #> Warning: glm.fit: fitted probabilities numerically 0 or 1 occurred s2 <- surrogate(fm2) scatter.smooth(x, s2 - fm2$linear.predictors,                main = "Correctly specified model",                ylab = "Surrogate residual",                lpars = list(lwd = 3, col = "red2")) abline(h = 0, lty = 2, col = "blue2")    dev.off() # reset to defaults once finish #> null device  #>           1

what: Hypothesis testing of the partial association coefficients — test
title: Hypothesis testing of the partial association coefficients — test
text: function use bootstrapping conduct hypothesis testing partial association coefficients. directly applies onto "PAsso" class object generated "PAsso".

title: Hypothesis testing of the partial association coefficients — test
code: test(object, bootstrap_rep = 300, H0 = 0, parallel = FALSE)

title: Hypothesis testing of the partial association coefficients — test
text: object object "PAsso" class, generated "PAsso" function. bootstrap_rep number bootstrap replications. may slow. H0 null hypothesis partial correlation coefficient. parallel logical argument whether conduct parallel bootstrapping partial association.

title: Hypothesis testing of the partial association coefficients — test
code: # Import ANES2016 data in "PAsso" data(ANES2016) # Parial association: PAsso_2v <- PAsso(responses = c("PreVote.num", "PID"),                 adjustments = c("income.num", "age", "edu.year"),                 data = ANES2016)  summary(PAsso_2v, digits=4) #> --------------------------------------------  #> The partial correlation coefficient matrix:  #>  #>              PreVote.num  PID    #> PreVote.num  1.0000       0.4492 #> PID                       1.0000 #> --------------------------------------------  #> The marginal correlation coefficient matrix:  #>  #>              PreVote.num  PID    #> PreVote.num  1.0000       0.7059 #> PID                       1.0000 #>  #> -------------------------------------------- #> -------------------------------------------- #>  #> The coefficients of fitted models are:  #>  #>             PreVote.num  PID        #> income.num   0.0005       0.0009*   #> Std. Error   0.0005       0.0004    #> ---                                 #> age          0.0092***    0.0048*** #> Std. Error   0.0016       0.0013    #> ---                                 #> edu.year    -0.0798***   -0.0459*** #> Std. Error   0.0117       0.0098    #> ---                                 #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1  PAsso_2v_test <- test(object = PAsso_2v, bootstrap_rep=20, H0=0, parallel=FALSE) #> The bootstrapping procedure may be slow when bootstrap_rep is large! PAsso_2v_test #> --------------------------------------------  #> The partial association analysis:  #>  #>              PreVote.num  PID    #> PreVote.num  1.0000       0.4492 #> S.E.                      0.006  #> Pr                        0.05*  #> ---                              #> PID                       1.0000 #> S.E.                             #> Pr                               #> ---                              #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1

title: PAsso 0.1.6
text: Add ‘diagnostic.plot’ replace ‘check.model’ diagnostics fitted models PAsso object. ‘autoplot’ become internal S3 method. S3 ‘diagnostic.plot’ method can deal classes PAsso, PAsso.test, resid, clm, glm, lrm, orm, polr. keep one nes2016 dataset. Change ‘resids’ function S3 method ‘residuals’, consistent R core ‘stats’ package. Conduct test ‘testthat’ avoid bugs methods applied different classes.

title: PAsso 0.1.6
text: Jittering probability scale currently supported logit-type models. issues ‘plot’ ‘diagnostic.plot’.

title: PAsso 0.1.5
text: Replace ‘cor’ function ‘pcaPP::cor.fk(X)’ speed PAsso(). Finalize S3 methods ‘summary.PAsso’ ‘print.PAsso.test’ provide clean results.

title: PAsso 0.1.5
text: digits print summary consistent. manual updated S3 ‘autoplot’ shortened. check.model qq-plot fixed.

title: PAsso 0.1.4
text: Change name package “PAsso”. Change autoplot function S3 method.
